final_policy.scenario: A previously healthy 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after an unwitnessed generalized tonic–clonic seizure that lasted about six minutes. final_policy.scenario: A 71-year-old man with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma undergoes routine surveillance brain MRI. final_policy.scenario: A 68-year-old man presents with a 24-hour history of sudden, profound hearing loss in his left ear accompanied by a sensation of fullness. He denies vertigo, tinnitus, headache, recent upper-respiratory infection, medication changes, or trauma. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a kidney transplant in 2013; he takes tacrolimus. Vital signs are stable. Otoscopic examination reveals normal external auditory canals and intact tympanic membranes. Bedside tuning-fork testing localises sound to the right ear on Weber and shows air > bone conduction bilaterally on Rinne, suggesting left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

mcqs.question: Pure-tone audiometry performed within 24 hours confirms an 80–90 dB sensorineural loss in the left ear with normal thresholds on the right. The patient is able to swallow medications and has no gastrointestinal comorbidity. According to current guideline-based management of sudden sensorineural hearing loss, which of the following is the most appropriate first-line therapy to initiate within the first 72 hours?

options.A: High-dose oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (maximum 60 mg) once daily in the morning for 3 days; if effective, continue for 2 more days and then stop without taper
options.B: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 250 mg/day for 3 days followed by taper
options.C: Oral prednisone 60 mg daily plus oral valacyclovir 1 g three times daily
options.D: Oral valacyclovir 1 g three times daily as monotherapy
options.F: Primary hyperbaric oxygen therapy without steroids
options.G: Low-salt diet with oral thiazide diuretic
options.I: Observation only, with no pharmacologic intervention
options.J: Intratympanic gentamicin injection to the affected ear

mcqs.question: After 6 days of high-dose oral prednisone, repeat audiometry shows only minimal improvement (threshold 72 dB). The patient now has marked hyperglycaemia and mood lability attributed to systemic steroids. Which of the following is the most appropriate next (salvage) step to attempt further auditory recovery?

options.A: Intratympanic corticosteroid injections to the left ear
options.B: Intratympanic corticosteroid injections combined with hyperbaric oxygen therapy
options.C: Continue the same dose of oral prednisone for another 7 days
options.E: Begin oral valacyclovir 1 g three times daily as sole therapy
options.F: Start daily aspirin 325 mg for presumed vascular aetiology
options.G: Initiate low-salt diet plus hydrochlorothiazide for suspected endolymphatic hydrops
options.I: Administer intratympanic gentamicin to ablate vestibular function
options.J: Begin carbamazepine for presumed neuropathic pain

final_policy.scenario: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 5 days of progressive shortness of breath and sharp left-sided chest discomfort that worsens on inspiration. One month earlier she had a mild, fully resolved COVID-19 infection. Her history includes repaired congenital heart disease and placement of a stent in the left pulmonary artery (LPA) at age 15 for residual stenosis; she has been asymptomatic and physically active since. On arrival: T 36.8 °C, BP 118/72 mm Hg, HR 92 beats/min, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO₂ 93 % on room air. Lung fields are clear and the cardiac examination is unremarkable. A contrast-enhanced CT angiogram of the chest is obtained (Figure 1A).

mcqs.question: Based on Figure 1A and the clinical presentation, which diagnosis most plausibly explains the patient’s acute dyspnoea?

options.A: Acute thrombosis of the pre-existing left pulmonary artery stent
options.B: Fresh saddle pulmonary embolus straddling the main pulmonary bifurcation
options.C: Acute segmental pulmonary embolism in the right lower lobe branches
options.D: In-situ thrombosis of a right pulmonary artery branch unrelated to the stent
options.F: Diffuse alveolar haemorrhage secondary to vasculitis
options.H: Type B aortic dissection with pleural effusion
options.I: Large pericardial effusion causing tamponade physiology
options.J: Tension pneumothorax of the left hemithorax

mcqs.question: Right-heart catheterisation shows: mean pulmonary artery pressure 62 mm Hg, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure 14 mm Hg, pulmonary vascular resistance 20 Wood units. In this clinical context, which WHO classification of pulmonary hypertension is most appropriate?

options.A: WHO Group 1: Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension
options.B: WHO Group 2: Pulmonary hypertension due to left-sided heart disease
options.C: WHO Group 3: Pulmonary hypertension secondary to post-COVID fibrotic lung disease
options.D: WHO Group 4: Chronic thrombo-embolic or other pulmonary artery obstruction
options.E: WHO Group 5: Pulmonary hypertension with multifactorial mechanisms (e.g., sarcoidosis)
options.F: Combined pre- and post-capillary pulmonary hypertension
options.G: High-output pulmonary hypertension from systemic-to-pulmonary shunt
options.I: Pulmonary hypertension associated with portal hypertension
options.J: Pulmonary hypertension in congenital cyanotic heart disease after Fontan surgery

mcqs.question: Selective pulmonary angiography (Figure 1E) demonstrates markedly reduced flow beyond the LPA stent. Which interventional strategy is the most appropriate immediate next step to attempt to restore perfusion?

options.A: Catheter-directed thrombolysis to the occluded left pulmonary artery segment
options.B: Immediate surgical pulmonary endarterectomy under deep hypothermic circulatory arrest
options.C: Percutaneous balloon pulmonary angioplasty of segmental branches alone
options.D: Initiate dual-oral pulmonary vasodilator therapy without further intervention
options.E: Mechanical aspiration thrombectomy using a large-bore catheter
options.F: High-dose intravenous corticosteroids for suspected vasculitis
options.G: Placement of an inferior vena cava filter without changing anticoagulation
options.H: Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy for presumed septic emboli
options.J: Early referral for combined heart–lung transplantation during this admission

mcqs.question: Three months later, repeat angiography (Figure 1F) shows complete occlusion distal to the fractured stent despite prior catheter-directed thrombolysis and balloon dilatation. She remains markedly exercise-limited and requires supplemental oxygen. She has been anticoagulated, could not tolerate maximal riociguat because of severe rash, and previously failed sildenafil and macitentan. What is the most appropriate next step in her long-term management?

options.A: Refer for formal evaluation for lung or heart–lung transplantation
options.B: Schedule staged series of balloon pulmonary angioplasty procedures to the occluded left pulmonary artery
options.C: Re-challenge with high-dose riociguat despite prior intolerance
options.D: Add warfarin to apixaban for dual anticoagulation
options.E: Implant a prophylactic inferior vena cava filter
options.F: Begin prolonged course of high-dose oral prednisone for presumed organising pneumonitis
options.G: Attempt surgical pulmonary endarterectomy of the distal stented segment
options.H: Initiate chronic ambulatory extracorporeal membrane oxygenation as bridge-to-decision
options.I: Enroll in pulmonary rehabilitation alone without additional therapy
options.J: Perform bronchial thermoplasty to improve airflow

He reports mild left-sided abdominal discomfort and 1–2 loose, occasionally blood-streaked bowel movements per day. He has been taking oral mesalamine 4 g daily without interruption for the past year and is otherwise healthy. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals multiple erythematous plaques studded with tense vesicles and bullae on the abdomen, arms, and legs. Figure 1 shows a photograph of his skin at presentation.

final_policy.scenario: A 69-year-old retired veterinarian from rural Greece arrives at the emergency department after suddenly developing profound weakness in both lower limbs over 4–5 h. He reports complete numbness below the waist and inability to void urine. There is no trauma or back pain. He regularly assists with livestock births and often eats unpasteurised goat cheese. Past medical history includes hypertension treated with perindopril and indapamide, and intermittent low-dose aspirin use. On examination he is afebrile, alert and oriented; power in both lower limbs is 0/5, tone is flaccid, reflexes are absent, all modalities of sensation are lost below the umbilicus, and a distended bladder is palpable.

mcqs.question: Which single investigation should be performed first to identify the cause of this patient’s acute spinal cord syndrome?

final_policy.scenario: A 21-year-old college chemistry student (65 kg) is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after intentionally ingesting an unlabeled “industrial white powder” that he had purchased online as a laboratory rodenticide. He reports one episode of vomiting after drinking a glass of milk at home. On arrival he complains of nausea, burning epigastric pain, dizziness, and progressive weakness of both legs. Vital signs: temperature 36.7 °C, blood pressure 133/79 mm Hg, heart rate 48 beats / min, respiratory rate 20 breaths / min, oxygen saturation 98 % on room air. Neurologic examination shows generalized hypotonia and 4/5 strength in the lower extremities; cranial nerves and deep-tendon reflexes are otherwise normal. Arterial blood gas: pH 7.31, PaCO₂ 4.4 kPa (33 mm Hg), HCO₃⁻ 17 mmol/L. Serum sodium 138 mmol/L, chloride 103 mmol/L; the remainder of the chemistry panel (including potassium) is pending. A 12-lead ECG obtained on arrival is shown (Figure 1).

mcqs.question: Based on the clinical presentation and Figure 1 only, which single electrolyte disturbance best accounts for the bradycardia, muscular weakness, and ECG pattern observed?

options.J: Primary metabolic acidosis without an electrolyte disorder

mcqs.question: Seven hours after ingestion, the patient is more fatigued and a repeat chemistry panel shows serum potassium 1.8 mmol/L. A plain chest radiograph (Figure 3a) is obtained. Considering the new information, which ingested toxin most plausibly explains the imaging appearance, the profound hypokalaemia, and the clinical course?
